sen.e: Irizake is a Japanese old seasoning used in the Edo period, which is made by putting umeboshi (pickled Japanese apricot) into Japanese sake, and boiling it down.

sen.j: 室町時代末期に考案されたといわれており、江戸時代中期まではタレと伴に広く用いられた液体調味料である。

sen.j: 江戸時代中期から醤油が普及するにしたがい次第に利用されなくなり、現在では一般に利用される事はほとんど無い。
sen.e: After soy sauce spread in the middle of the Edo period, it gradually bacame not to be used, and in present days, it is rarely used commonly.

sen.j: 醤油のような強い個性を持たず素材の風味を生かすので、白身魚や貝類の刺身に相性がよい。
sen.e: Since it doesn't have strong characteristics like soy sauce and makes good use of the flavors of materials, it goes well with sashimi (fresh slices of raw fish) of whitefish (a fish with white flesh) and shellfish.

sen.j: 『料理物語』によれば、「熬酒は鰹一升に梅干十五乃至二十、古酒二升、水少々、溜り少々を入れて一升に煎じ、漉し冷してよし、また酒二升、水一升入れて二升に煎じ使ふ人もある。煮出酒は、鰹に塩少々加へ、新酒で一泡二泡煎じ、漉し冷してよろし、精進の熬酒は、豆腐を田楽ほどに切り、炙つて、梅干、干蕪など刻み入れ、古酒で煎じてよし」という。
sen.e: According to "Ryori Monogatari" (tale of food), it is recorded that 'Irizake is made by putting fifteen to twenty umeboshi, 2 sho (unit of volume, approx. 1.8 liters) of old sake, little water, and little tamari (rich soy sauce) into 1 sho of dried bonito and boiling it down to 1 sho, filtering it and cooling it, and also, there are some people putting 2 sho of sake and 1 sho of water, boiling down to 2 sho.

sen.e: "Ryori Monogatari" (tale of food) records that 'Irizake is made by putting 15-20 umeboshi, 2 sho (approx. 1.8 liters) of old sake, a little water, and a little tamari (rich soy sauce) into 1 sho of dried bonito before reducing it down to 1 sho, filtering it and cooling it, while there are some people who add 2 sho of sake and 1 sho of water before reducing it down to 2 sho; Nidashizake (extracted sake) is made by adding a little salt to dried bonito and boiling it for a while with new sake, filtering it and cooling it; and shojin irizake is made by putting chopped umeboshi and hoshi kabura (dried turnips) into grilled tofu with size of dengaku, and boiling it with old sake.'
